chapters.title: Exploring the Question of Identity
paragraphs: Throughout our lives, we often grapple with one profound question: "Who am I really?" The answer to this question is rarely clear. Some days, we may feel completely in touch with our identity, while on other days, we find ourselves feeling lost and disconnected. If you relate more to that second feeling, I understand you completely.

For much of my life, I struggled with self-criticism and sought someone or something to finally "fix" me. I constantly yearned for a fresh start because I never felt like I was living the life I wanted. At the same time, I was afraid of making mistakes and hesitant to embrace new experiences. I felt trapped in a cycle of wanting to change while being paralyzed by the fear of disrupting what I thought I knew about myself.

I spent years oscillating between self-discovery and self-neglect until I finally came to a life-changing realization: I am not broken, and I don’t need to fix myself. Embracing authenticity is, in fact, quite simple. The biggest obstacle to being authentic often stems from a fundamental misunderstanding of what it means to be true to oneself.

chapters.title: The Journey of Self-Discovery
paragraphs: I mistook authenticity for perfection, and as a result, I became disappointed in myself for not being my best self all the time. This led to feelings of brokenness, as I identified with every mistake I made, each bad mood I experienced, and the negative thoughts that lingered in my mind.

The first thing you need to realize is that you should stop trying to fix yourself. You are okay just the way you are. Your authentic self is not an idealized version of you; it encompasses all parts of you, including those you like and those you tend to neglect. We are born authentic, but through the conditioning we experience in life, we begin to build a shell based on the fear of judgment from others.

In trying to fit into societal norms or impress others, we gradually lose touch with our true selves. While being influenced by our surroundings is inevitable, we can choose to what extent that influence affects us. It is essential to form your own life principles and opinions, recognizing the green and red flags in your experiences. If you lack an opinion, others will readily provide one for you. Embracing your authenticity means recognizing and valuing all aspects of who you are, rather than striving for an unattainable perfection.

To discover your own values, it's essential to minimize distractions and engage in self-reflection. This involves cutting out external noise and sitting in silence, even embracing moments of boredom. Take time to meditate and journal, asking yourself meaningful questions to uncover what truly matters to you.

While forming your own strong opinions, it's important to remain open to other viewpoints. However, be cautious not to adopt these perspectives as your own the moment you hear them. The process of discovering your authenticity is not about adding new elements to your identity; rather, it is about removing the barriers that prevent you from being who your heart truly calls you to be.

Letting go of fears related to judgment, rejection, and failure is crucial. Embracing your uniqueness and feeling free to express yourself—regardless of how different or unconventional that might be—is a vital aspect of authenticity. When those fears inevitably arise, which is completely natural, it’s important not to let them hinder your true self.

Ultimately, I strive to enjoy every moment of my life without second-guessing my choices. The next time you find yourself feeling overwhelmed or caught up in external pressures, remember the importance of returning to your authentic self.

In recognizing our limitations, it is essential to do ourselves a favor by letting go of resistance. Instead of fighting against the positive and negative thoughts that arise, as well as the various emotions and fears—both big and small—we should allow these feelings to flow freely. Overthinking and resistance often lead to discomfort, while taking action, even when it feels daunting, can be liberating.

To move forward, it is crucial to step out of our heads and disidentify from the incessant mental chatter. Learning to observe and filter our thoughts can foster a healthier mindset. I strongly advocate for embracing the spiritual aspect of our lives, as I believe we are not solely our minds. We are, fundamentally, souls, and our minds serve as instruments that we should use to our advantage.

Trusting our bodies and intuition is vital, as they possess knowledge far beyond what our minds can comprehend. They are reliable guides that never deceive us. Engaging in self-care practices—such as maintaining a regular exercise routine, ensuring proper nutrition, and actively listening to ourselves—can significantly enhance our well-being.

Entering high vibrational states such as love, gratitude, trust, and hope can significantly enhance your daily life. For me, some life-changing practices include morning prayer and evening meditation. The early morning and late evening are optimal times for engaging with your subconscious, which is more receptive to positive thoughts and energy during these hours. Filling your mind with uplifting content at these times can profoundly impact how you feel and exist in the world.

Additionally, tapping into creative activities that you enjoy can help you naturally enter a flow state. Engaging in these activities allows you to explore your inner self and uncover insights from your subconscious. It is essential to experiment with your routines to discover what works best for you, as each person's needs are unique.

Creating a filter to process everything you see and hear in your environment is also crucial. You can view every incoming suggestion as something you can either accept or decline. Remember, you always have the option to say, "No thanks, I'm not taking that in." This practice is about establishing boundaries, particularly with people in your life. The boundaries I discuss here are special and serve to protect your emotional and mental well-being.

chapters.title: Embracing Authenticity: The Path to Self-Acceptance
paragraphs: We have several types of boundaries that are essential for our well-being. Physical boundaries prevent strangers from invading our personal space, such as an unwelcome kiss, and keep us safe from harm. Verbal boundaries protect us from inappropriate comments or jokes that target us. However, many people overlook the importance of energetic boundaries.

Signs of poor energetic boundaries include frequently engaging in arguments, being negatively impacted by a rude taxi driver, or easily absorbing other people's negativity. It's crucial to stop allowing external energies that do not resonate with us to affect our emotional state. When we permit too much outside energy into our lives, we risk burying our authenticity beneath it.

To cultivate strong energetic boundaries, it’s important to connect with your own energetic field—your aura. Take time to reflect on its color, shape, and the types of energy it holds. Determine which energies are allowed within your space to protect yourself from vibrations that are lower than yours. I find great value in perceiving communication with my environment through this lens. By being authentic and safeguarded by my own energy, I can decide how much of my energy I am willing to exchange with others.

In reflecting on authenticity and society, it's important to recognize that nobody truly gives up on how you live your life. As years pass by, you may find that when you die, no one will know even 10% of your story, especially the small details that mean so much to you. Understanding this can be incredibly freeing.

Instead of conforming to what you believe others expect from you, I encourage you to embrace all the unique and quirky aspects of yourself. Connect with your inner child and allow yourself to have fun. Simple joys, like jumping in puddles on a rainy day or singing loudly just for the sake of it, can be profound expressions of authenticity.
As you explore what it means to be authentic in your own life, remember that you are okay just the way you are. Embrace your true self and let it shine.

chapters.title: Breaking Free from External Influences
paragraphs: Many people often express the idea that you don't need to change, and I have disagreed with this notion. It does not imply that there is no growth or self-improvement. In fact, there is a distinction between your authentic self and your highest self. Your authentic self encompasses who you inherently are, including your traits and personality. Embracing these qualities is essential for becoming your highest self—the version of you that you aspire to be.

This highest self could be someone who speaks publicly, builds a successful career, and travels the world. In a previous video, I discussed how to achieve this highest version of yourself, which many of you appreciated. I highly recommend watching that video after this one.

It's important to recognize that these two versions of yourself should coexist for a sense of balance. You cannot become your highest self without maintaining your authenticity. The mistakes you make or the experiences you have cannot strip away your authenticity. Your authentic self is uniquely you, and no one can take that away from you. Authenticity is your freedom and your power.

Standing out from the crowd and embracing your uniqueness can often feel uncomfortable. However, if you find yourself in such a situation, congratulations! You are on the right path. Your individuality is your greatest asset; it opens doors that are meant for you and not for others.

Being authentic allows you the freedom to decide how to live your life. In contrast, living an average existence and trying to conform neither serves your own interests nor contributes meaningfully to the world. Those who fear being authentic often work for those who are not afraid to embrace their true selves. It is these individuals, who dare to be genuine, that have the power to change the world.
